title_sort: walt whitman to john h. johnston, 25 september [1877]
title: Walt Whitman to John H. Johnston, 25 September [1877]
text: 431 Stevens StreetCamden New JerseySeptSeptember 25Dear JohnstonHow are you—& all?—I want to hear about Al and May—& I want to hear about the baby—Please do a little thing for me—there was a white tea-cup & saucer, a "moustache-cup" given me by a soldier, & I left it at your house—if it is unbroken & still there, please have some of your fellows box it neatly & express it here to me—How are all your fellows in the store? Tell them I remember them all so well & so pleasantly——I have been down in the country at a secluded primitive farm all summer, living much of the time outdoors by a solitary woody pond, (half the time naked or half-naked)—am now quite fat & all tanned & red—Love to you, my friend—Walt WWhere & how is Waters? Where is the picture? Walt Whitman to John H. Johnston, 25 September [1877]
